lines.text: [ordering a drink]
The you best you have... Is this your best?
You can't get better south to Dawson or north to Nome.
I know that when I started your copper mine here, sir, you figured on getting Bailey's equipment cheap as part of the deal, but if he means what he says...
I don't care what he says. I want his milling machinery at any price. The cost of shipping heavy machinery like that is prohibitive.
We could let him do our milling for our copper for us if he gave you a percentage.
And be at Bailey's mercy? Oh, no. Ownership of that mill is the difference between profit and loss for the Decker copper mine.
I see. No mill, no job for me running the mine - is that it?
I don't start anything I can't control. That's why I make money and Bailey goes broke
So LaRock paid me two nuggets for telling him where I thought Bailey had found the gold. It wasn't one of my better predictions.
That was the first time you saw the ring?
Yes. The other time was just before you entered. Seems Blackie felt he hadn't got his money's worth and came back and took a refund with interest.
The last talk I had with you - and it was quite a while ago - still stands. You remember it?
Wasn't it something to the effect of - I was on my own unless I worked for the Decker Company.
That's right. You're on your own until you came to your senses. You obviously haven't so there's nothing more to be said.
I'm afraid there is, Dad. You see the objective I raised at that time over you ruthless business methods has cropped up again in this case.
What? Is anything more ruthless then setting a son against his father?
I ain't sayin' I didn't cheat. I am sayin' I did it a little better than you and I'm taking your winnings.
The trail of a clever man who's behind your father's murder, June, isn't as easy as all that.
I know, Wayne, and I'm sorry, but sometimes, well...
Let me say it for you. Constable claims my father is guilty of your father's death and sometimes you suspect me of trying to shield Dad.
How can I help it?
By having faith in the service as it has in me. You can't find any double-dealers in the records of the Mounties.
[last lines]
My pappy always told me the Mounties always get what they go after.
And your pappy was right, Bucket. Don't you think so, June?
Yes, if you say so, Wayne.
This is what I get for being constable. The corporal, he always gets the first bird.
Yes, but when the ladies go after their man, even a corporal in the Mounted doesn't stand a chance.
